views.text: Windows Search lets you search your stuff and the web from one place. If you choose to use Windows Search to search "your stuff," it will provide results for items on your personal OneDrive, your OneDrive for Business if so enabled, other cloud storage providers to the extent supported by those third-party providers, and on your device. If you choose to use Windows Search to search the web, or get search suggestions with Windows Search, your search results will be powered by Bing and we will use your search query as described in the Bing section of this privacy statement. Learn more about search in Windows (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=2106608).
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776>Windows Search lets you search your stuff and the </button>

views.text: Entertainment and related services
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776>Entertainment and related services</button>

views.text: Entertainment and Related Services power rich experiences and enable you to access a variety of content, applications and games.
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776>Entertainment and Related Services power rich expe</button>

views.text: Xbox
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776>Xbox</button>

views.text: The Xbox network is the online gaming and entertainment service from Microsoft that consists of software and enables online experiences across different platforms. This service lets you find and play games, view content, and connect with friends on Xbox and other gaming and social networks.
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776>The Xbox network is the online gaming and entertai</button>

views.text: When you sign up for an Xbox profile, we assign you a gamertag (a public nickname) and a unique identifier. When you sign in on Xbox devices, apps, and services, the data we collect about your use is stored using these unique identifier(s).
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776>When you sign up for an Xbox profile, we assign yo</button>

views.text: Xbox consoles are devices you can use to find and play games, movies, music, and other digital entertainment. When you sign in to Xbox experiences—in apps or on a console—we also assign a unique identifier to your device. When your Xbox console is connected to the internet, for instance, and you sign in to the console, we identify which console and which version of the console’s operating system you’re using.
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776>Xbox consoles are devices you can use to find and </button>

views.text: Xbox continues to provide new experiences in client apps that are connected to and backed by services such as the Xbox network and cloud gaming. When signed in to an Xbox experience, we collect required data to help keep these experiences reliable, up to date, secure, and performing as expected.
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776>Xbox continues to provide new experiences in clien</button>

views.text: Data we collect about your use of Xbox services, games, apps, and consoles includes:
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776>Data we collect about your use of Xbox services, g</button>

views.text: • When you sign in and sign out of Xbox, any purchases you make, and content you obtain.
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776> • When you sign in and sign out of Xbox, any purc</button>

views.text: • Which games you play and apps you use, your game progress, achievements, play time per game, and other play statistics.
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776> • Which games you play and apps you use, your gam</button>

views.text: • Performance data about Xbox consoles, Xbox Game Pass and other Xbox apps, the Xbox network, connected accessories, and your network connection, including any software or hardware errors.
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776> • Performance data about Xbox consoles, Xbox Game</button>

views.text: • Content you add, upload, or share through the Xbox network, including text, pictures, and video you capture in games and apps.
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776> • Content you add, upload, or share through the X</button>

views.text: • Social activity, including chat data and interactions with other gamers, and connections you make (friends you add and people who follow you) on the Xbox network.
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776> • Social activity, including chat data and intera</button>

views.text: If you sign in to use Xbox on another device capable of accessing the Xbox network, and that device includes a storage device (hard drive or memory unit), usage data will be stored on the storage device and sent to Microsoft the next time you sign in to Xbox, even if you’ve been playing offline.
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776>If you sign in to use Xbox on another device capab</button>

views.text: Camera and Microphone. While using Xbox, players can use the device’s capabilities such as the microphone, camera and screen recording to improve their gaming experience. When an Xbox game is played in the Windows Game Bar, the camera and microphone may be used, including to read photos and videos and to capture and record screenshots.
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776>Camera and Microphone. While using Xbox, players c</button>

views.text: Xbox diagnostic data. Diagnostic data has two categories: required and optional.
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776>Xbox diagnostic data. Diagnostic data has two cate</button>

views.text: • Required. Xbox will send required data to Microsoft. The minimum data necessary to help keep Xbox safe, secure, up to date, and performing as expected.
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776> • Required. Xbox will send required data to Micro</button>

views.text: • Optional. Optional data is additional data that you choose to share with Microsoft. Optional data may include additional details about the operation, usage, and performance of your Xbox products and services, as well as enhanced error reporting.
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776> • Optional. Optional data is additional data that</button>

views.text: Learn more at Manage settings for optional data sharing (https://www.xbox.com/managedatacollection).
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776>Learn more at Manage settings for optional data sh</button>

views.text: Game captures. Any player in a multiplayer game session can record video (game clips) and capture screenshots of their view of the game play. Other players’ game clips and screenshots can capture your in-game character and gamertag during that session. If a player captures game clips and screenshots on a PC, the resulting game clips might also capture audio chat.
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776>Game captures. Any player in a multiplayer game se</button>

views.text: Captioning. During Xbox real-time (“party”) chat, players may activate a voice-to-text feature that lets them view that chat as text. If a player activates this feature, all voice communication in the party is captioned for the player. Microsoft uses the resulting text data to provide captioning of chat for players who need it, as well as the other purposes described in this statement.
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776>Captioning. During Xbox real-time (“party”) chat, </button>

views.text: Data use. Microsoft uses the data we collect to improve gaming products and experiences—making them safer and more fun over time.
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776>Data use. Microsoft uses the data we collect to im</button>

views.text: Data we collect also enables us to provide you with curated experiences. This includes connecting you to games, content, and services, as well as presenting you with offers, discounts, and recommendations. To change your settings for these recommendations, visit Xbox online safety and privacy settings (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=2170314) page.
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776>Data we collect also enables us to provide you wit</button>

views.text: Xbox data viewable by others. Your gamertag, game and play statistics, achievements, presence (whether you are currently signed in to Xbox), content you share, and other data about your activity on Xbox can be seen by:
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776>Xbox data viewable by others. Your gamertag, game </button>

views.text: • Other players signed in to Xbox.
views.signature: [class]android.view.View[resource_id]None[text] • Other players signed in to Xbox. [enabled,,]
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776> • Other players signed in to Xbox. </button>

views.text: Xbox data shared with third parties including game and apps publishers. When you use an Xbox online game or any network-connected app on your Xbox console, PC, or mobile device, the publisher of that game or app has access to data about your usage to help the publisher deliver, support, and improve its product. This data may include: your Xbox user identifier, gamertag, limited account info such as country and age range, data about your in-game communications, any Xbox enforcement activity, game-play sessions (for example, moves made in-game, types of vehicles used in-game), your presence on the Xbox network, the time you spend playing the game or app, rankings, statistics, gamer profiles, avatars, or gamerpics, friends lists, activity feeds for official clubs you belong to, official club memberships, and any content you create or submit in the game or app.
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776>Xbox data shared with third parties including game</button>

views.text: Third-party publishers and developers of games and apps have their own distinct and independent relationship with users and their collection and usage of personal data is subject to their specific privacy policies. You should carefully review their policies to determine how they use the data. For example, publishers may choose to disclose or display game data (such as on leaderboards) through their own services. You may find their policies linked from game or app detail pages in the Microsoft Store.

Adult organizers in your Microsoft family group can change consent choices and online safety settings for child and teen profiles on Xbox.com (https://www.xbox.com/).

views.text: Safety. In order to help make the Xbox network a safe gaming environment and enforce the Community Standards for Xbox, we may collect and review voice, text, images, videos and in-game content (such as game clips you upload, conversations you have, and things you post in clubs and games).
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776>Safety. In order to help make the Xbox network a s</button>

views.text: Anti-cheat and fraud prevention. Providing a fair gameplay environment is important to us. We prohibit cheating, hacking, account stealing, and any other unauthorized or fraudulent activity when you use an Xbox online game or any network-connected app on your Xbox console, PC, or mobile device. In order to detect and prevent fraud and cheating, we may use anti-cheat and fraud prevention tools, applications, and other technologies. Such technologies may create digital signatures (known as “hashes”) using certain information collected from your Xbox console, PC, or mobile device, and how you use that device. This can include information about the browser, device, activities, game identifiers, and operating system.
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776>Anti-cheat and fraud prevention. Providing a fair </button>

views.text: Microsoft Store
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776>Microsoft Store</button>

views.text: Microsoft Store is an online service, accessible via PC, the Xbox Console and the Xbox App, that allows you to browse, download, purchase, rate, and review applications and other digital content. It includes:
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776>Microsoft Store is an online service, accessible v</button>

views.text: • Apps and content for Windows devices such as phones, PCs, and tablets.
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776> • Apps and content for Windows devices such as ph</button>

views.text: • Games, subscriptions and other apps for Xbox consoles and other devices.
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776> • Games, subscriptions and other apps for Xbox co</button>

views.text: • Products and apps for Microsoft 365, SharePoint, Exchange, Access, and Project (2013 versions or later).
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776> • Products and apps for Microsoft 365, SharePoint</button>

views.text: We collect data about how you access and use Microsoft Store; the products you've viewed, purchased, or installed; the preferences you set for viewing apps in Microsoft Store; and any ratings, reviews, or problem reports you submit. Your Microsoft account is associated with your ratings and reviews; and if you write a review, the name and picture from your Microsoft account will be published with your review. Microsoft Store uses the region configured on your device to show relevant and eligible content and merchandising. Microsoft Store uses your device identifier to manage product rights tied to a specific device.
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776>We collect data about how you access and use Micro</button>

views.text: Permission for Microsoft Store apps. Many apps you install from the Microsoft Store are designed to take advantage of specific hardware and software features of your device. An app's use of certain hardware and software features may give the app or its related service access to your data. For example, a photo editing app might access your device's camera to let you take a new photo or access photos or videos stored on your device for editing, and a restaurant guide might use your location to provide nearby recommendations. Information about the features that an app uses is provided on the app's product description page in Microsoft Store. Many of the features that Microsoft Store apps use can be turned on or off through your device’s privacy settings. In Windows, in many cases, you can choose which apps can use a particular feature. Go to Start > Settings > Privacy or Privacy & Security, select the feature (for example, Calendar), and then select which app permissions are on or off. The lists of apps in Windows privacy settings that can use hardware and software features will not include "Classic Windows" applications, and these applications are not affected by these settings.
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776>Permission for Microsoft Store apps. Many apps you</button>

views.text: App updates. Unless you have turned off automatic app updates in the relevant Microsoft Store settings or have acquired an app provided and updated by the app developer, Microsoft Store will automatically check for, download, and install app updates to verify that you have the latest versions. Updated apps might use different Windows hardware and software features from the previous versions, which could give them access to different data on your device. You will be prompted for consent if an updated app accesses certain features, such as location. You can also review the hardware and software features an app uses by viewing its product description page in Microsoft Store.
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776>App updates. Unless you have turned off automatic </button>

views.text: Each app's use of your data collected through any of these features is subject to the app developer's privacy policies. If an app available through Microsoft Store collects and uses any of your personal data, the app developer is required to provide a privacy policy, and a link to the privacy policy is available on the app's product description page in Microsoft Store.
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776>Each app's use of your data collected through any </button>

views.text: Sideloaded apps and developer mode. Developer features such as the "developer mode" setting are intended for development use only. If you enable developer features, your device may become unreliable or unusable, and expose you to security risks. Downloading or otherwise acquiring apps from sources other than Microsoft Store, also known as "sideloading" apps, may make your device and personal data more vulnerable to attack or unexpected use by apps. Windows policies, notifications, permissions, and other features intended to help protect your privacy when apps access your data may not function as described in this statement for sideloaded apps or when developer features are enabled.
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776>Sideloaded apps and developer mode. Developer feat</button>

views.text: Microsoft Start
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776>Microsoft Start</button>

views.text: Microsoft Start (formerly known as MSN or Microsoft News) is a content service that includes news, weather, sports, and finance. The Microsoft Start app is available on various platforms, including iOS and Android. The Microsoft Start service is also included within other Microsoft services, including the Microsoft Edge browser and widgets on Windows.
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776>Microsoft Start (formerly known as MSN or Microsof</button>

views.text: When you install the Microsoft Start, MSN Weather, or Microsoft News apps, we collect data that tells us if the app was installed properly, the installation date, the app version, and other data about your device such as the operating system and browser. This data is collected on a regular basis to help us determine the number of app users and identify performance issues associated with different app versions, operating systems, and browsers.
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776>When you install the Microsoft Start, MSN Weather,</button>

views.text: We also collect data about how you interact with Microsoft Start content, such as usage frequency and articles viewed, to provide you with relevant content. Microsoft Start provides an enhanced experience when you sign in with your Microsoft account, including allowing you to customize your interests and favorites. We use your location to provide you with relevant content such as local weather and news. You can manage personalization through Microsoft Start and Bing settings, as well as through settings in other Microsoft services that include Microsoft Start services. We also use the data we collect to provide you with advertisements that may be of interest to you. You can opt out of interest-based advertising through the advertising links within Microsoft Start services, or by visiting the Microsoft opt-out page (http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=286759).
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776>We also collect data about how you interact with M</button>

views.text: Previous versions of MSN Money allow you to access personal finance information from third-party financial institutions. MSN Money only displays this information and does not store it on our servers. Your sign-in credentials used to access your financial information from third parties are encrypted on your device and are not sent to Microsoft. These financial institutions, as well as any other third-party services you access through MSN services, are subject to their own terms and privacy policies.
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776>Previous versions of MSN Money allow you to access</button>

views.text: Groove Music lets you easily play your music collection and make playlists. Microsoft Movies & TV allows you to play your video collection and rent or buy movies and TV episodes. These services were formerly offered as Xbox Music and Video.

views.text: To help you discover content that may interest you, Microsoft will collect data about what content you play, the length of play, and the rating you give it.
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776>To help you discover content that may interest you</button>

views.text: To enrich your experience when playing content, Groove Music and Movies & TV will display related information about the content you play and the content in your music and video libraries, such as the album title, cover art, song or video title, and other information, where available. To provide this information, Groove Music and Movies & TV send an information request to Microsoft containing standard device data, such as your device IP address, device software version, your regional and language settings, and an identifier for the content.
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776>To enrich your experience when playing content, Gr</button>

views.text: If you use Movies & TV to access content that has been protected with Microsoft Digital Rights Management (DRM), it may automatically request media usage rights from an online rights server and download and install DRM updates in order to let you play the content. See the DRM information in the Silverlight section of this privacy statement for more information.

views.text: Silverlight
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776>Silverlight</button>

views.text: Microsoft Silverlight helps you to access and enjoy rich content on the Web. Silverlight enables websites and services to store data on your device. Other Silverlight features involve connecting to Microsoft to obtain updates, or to Microsoft or third-party servers to play protected digital content.
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776>Microsoft Silverlight helps you to access and enjo</button>

views.text: Silverlight Configuration tool. You can make choices about these features in the Silverlight Configuration tool. To access the Silverlight Configuration tool, right click on content that is currently being displayed by Silverlight and select Silverlight. You can also run the Silverlight Configuration tool directly. In Windows, for example, you can access the tool by searching for "Microsoft Silverlight."
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776>Silverlight Configuration tool. You can make choic</button>

views.text: Silverlight application storage. Silverlight-based applications can store data files locally on your computer for a variety of purposes, including saving your custom settings, storing large files for graphically intensive features (such as games, maps, and images), and storing content that you create within certain applications. You can turn off or configure application storage in the Silverlight Configuration tool.
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776>Silverlight application storage. Silverlight-based</button>

views.text: Silverlight updates. Silverlight will periodically check a Microsoft server for updates to provide you with the latest features and improvements. A small file containing information about the latest Silverlight version will be downloaded to your computer and compared to your currently installed version. If a newer version is available, it will be downloaded and installed on your computer. You can turn off or configure updates in the Silverlight Configuration tool.
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776>Silverlight updates. Silverlight will periodically</button>

views.text: Digital Rights Management. Silverlight uses Microsoft Digital Rights Management (DRM) technology to help protect the rights of content owners. If you access DRM-protected content (such as music or video) with Silverlight, it will request media usage rights from a rights server on the Internet. In order to provide a seamless playback experience, you will not be prompted before Silverlight sends the request to the rights server. When requesting media usage rights, Silverlight will provide the rights server with an ID for the DRM-protected content file and basic data about your device, including data about the DRM components on your device such as their revision and security levels, and a unique identifier for your device.
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776>Digital Rights Management. Silverlight uses Micros</button>

views.text: DRM updates. In some cases, accessing DRM-protected content will require an update to Silverlight or to the DRM components on your device. When you attempt to play content that requires a DRM update, Silverlight will send a request to a Microsoft server containing basic data about your device, including information about the DRM components on your computer such as their revision and security levels, troubleshooting data, and a unique identifier for your device. The Microsoft server uses this identifier to return a unique DRM update for your device, which will then be installed by Silverlight. You can turn off or configure DRM component updates on the Playback tab in the Silverlight Configuration tool.
views.desc: <button bound_box=72,1773,1008,1776>DRM updates. In some cases, accessing DRM-protecte</button>

views.text: Microsoft collects diagnostic data to solve problems and to keep Mixed Reality running on Windows up to date, secure, and operating properly. Diagnostic data also helps us improve Mixed Reality and related Microsoft products and services depending on the diagnostic data settings you’ve chosen for your device. Learn more about Windows diagnostic data.
